EARTH 2.title: Principles of Physical Geology
EARTH 2.description: Introduction to the science of the Earth; properties and processes of  its surface and interior, including plate tectonics, volcanism,    earthquakes, glaciation, mountain building, formation of rocks,    minerals, and the structural basis of landforms. Lab and lecture.

EARTH 2H.title: Principles of Physical Geology (Honors)
EARTH 2H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Earth 2; honors standing.
EARTH 2H.description: A supplement to Earth 2 focusing on properties and processes of the    Earth's surface and its interior, including plate tectonics, volcanism,  earthquakes, glaciation, mountain building, formation of rocks, minerals,  and the structural basis of landforms.

EARTH 3.title: Principles of Historical Geology
EARTH 3.description: Antiquity and history of the Earth from an Earth system history approach.  Focus is on processes and changes over time of the Earth's lithosphere,  biosphere, atmosphere, and hydrosphere.

EARTH 3H.title: Principles of Historical Geology (Honors)
EARTH 3H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Earth 3; honors standing.
EARTH 3H.description: A supplement to Earth 3 focusing on special topics in Earth system   history.

EARTH 3LX.title: Principles of Historical Geology (Laboratory)
EARTH 3LX.description: Elementary problems in paleontology and stratigraphy.

EARTH 4.title: Introduction to Oceanography
EARTH 4.description: An introduction to oceanography covering the major physical, chemical, and geological features of the oceans, their role in earth history, and    potential use as a natural resource. Lab and lecture.

EARTH 4H.title: Introduction to Oceanography (Honors)
EARTH 4H.prereq_description: Honors standing; concurrent enrollment in Earth 4.
EARTH 4H.description: A supplement to Earth 4 focusing on major physical, chemical, and    geological features of the oceans, their role in earth history, and  potential use as a natural resource.

EARTH 6.title: Mountains, Boots, and Backpacks: Field Study of the High Sierra
EARTH 6.comments: Open to non-majors. Need ability to hike 1-2 hours/day. Course materials fee charged.  Instructor approval required to finalize registration.   Priority enrollment to freshmen and sophomores.
EARTH 6.description: Ten-day, off-campus, field-based investigation of faults, volcanoes,   glaciers, rivers, and related geologic processes in the Sierra Nevada  and nearby mountains. Emphasis on observations; analysis of geologic and environmental field data. Held in September before the start of Fall   Quarter classes.

EARTH 7.title: Dinosaurs
EARTH 7.description: The origin and diversification of dinosaurs, including birds. Survey of  evolutionary relationships within the group, and between the major groups  of vertebrates. Broad introduction including anatomy, geography, climate,  and vertebrate contemporaries.

EARTH 7H.title: Dinosaurs (Honors)
EARTH 7H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Earth 7; honors standing.
EARTH 7H.description: A supplement to Earth 7 focusing on the origin and diversification of  dinosaurs, including birds. Survey of evolutionary relationships within  the group, and between the major groups of vertebrates. Broad introduction including anatomy, geography, climate, and vertebrate contemporaries.

EARTH 8.title: Africa: Climate and Human Evolution
EARTH 8.description: Our human ancestors (hominin) originated from Africa. Addresses both   major climate changes and steps in hominin evolution over the last 5   million years in Africa and discusses how climate and landscape changes  interacted to modulate hominin evolution.

EARTH 9.title: Giant Earthquakes
EARTH 9.description: Study of the character and causes of large earthquakes, the hazards they pose, and how society can prepare for and mitigate their impacts.    Historical case studies will illuminate why their slip characteristics and destructive effects vary so widely.

EARTH 10.title: Antarctica: The Last Place on Earth
EARTH 10.description: The interrelations of the physical and biological environments on the continent Antarctica; Antarctica as an earth system. Included are studies of tectonic history, global warming, ozone depletion, mineral resources, and the history of scientific exploration of the continent.

EARTH 11.title: Volcanoes and Humans
EARTH 11.description: An introduction to volcanism and its consequences. Origins and physical  processes of volcanism; the natural benefits of volcanoes; volcanic  hazards and disasters; volcanoes in human history, society, and culture; volcanoes and climate; volcano monitoring and hazard mitigation.

EARTH 12.title: Climate Change: Lessons from the Past
EARTH 12.description: Introduction to the fundamental forces that shape and modulate the Earth's climate. Learning about climate forcings (solar insolation, albedo, greenhouse effect, ocean circulation) will provide a scientific basis to understand past, current, and future climate changes.

EARTH 18.title: Field Studies in Geological Sciences
EARTH 18.comments: Quarters usually offered: Spring, Fall. Course Materials Fee charged.
EARTH 18.description: Four to five day field trip, fall and/or spring quarters. Field studies  under guidance of two or three staff members introducing the geology of  California.

EARTH 19.title: Geology of Yosemite Valley
EARTH 19.comments: Course materials fee charged. Open to lower division students.
EARTH 19.description: Introduction to the geology, surface processes, glacial history, and   environmental geology of Yosemite valley. The four-day field trip includes one day in the lower Yosemite valley, and one day in the upper valley.

EARTH 20.title: Geological Catastrophes
EARTH 20.description: Course deals with geologic catastrophes, e.g., earthquakes, vocanic    eruptions, tsunamis, and landslides. Students will learn the basic   physicalcauses of these naturally occurring events and discuss the   consequences.

EARTH 30.title: The History of Life
EARTH 30.description: Examination of the geological and biological processes affecting the   evolution of life on Earth from 3.8 billion years ago to the present.  Strong emphasis on the nature of the "scientific method" as a way of   understanding natural history.

EARTH 30H.title: History of Life (Honors)
EARTH 30H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Earth 30; honors standing.
EARTH 30H.description: Supplement of Earth 30 focusing on examination of geological and     biological processes affecting evolution of life on Earth from 3.8 billion years ago to present. Strong emphasis on the nature of the "scientific   method" as a way of understanding natural history.

EARTH 98.title: Readings in Geological Sciences
EARTH 98.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all  98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EARTH 98.description: Critical reviews and discussions of selected geological subjects.

EARTH 99.title: Independent Studies
EARTH 99.description: Independent research conducted under guidance of Earth Science faculty.  Topic and scope varies, to be specified by student and supervisory faculty member prior to registration.

EARTH 100.title: Introduction to Geophysics
EARTH 100.prereq_description: Mathematics 3C or Mathematics 4A and 4B; Physics 1, 2, and 3 (may be taken concurrently), or Physics 6A-B-C (may be taken concurrently).
EARTH 100.description: Survey of major topics in geophysics at an elementary level; the figure  of the earth, its gravitational and magnetic fields, seismology and the  deep structure of the earth, heat flow, methods of geophysical     exploration. The geophysical basis of plate tectonics and sea floor  spreading.

EARTH 102A.title: Petrology of Igneous Rocks
EARTH 102A.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A; and, Earth 114 and 115 with a grade of C or better.
EARTH 102A.description: Introduction to the occurrence, associations, tectonics, and     petrogenesis of plutonic and volcanic rocks. Introduction to the   physical chemistry of magma systems; magmatic crystallization and    differentiation; pluton emplacement, volcanic eruption mechanisms.   Lecture and lab.

EARTH 102B.title: Sedimentology Petrology
EARTH 102B.prereq_description: Geology 114 or 114A-B and 115. Concurrent enrollment with Geology 102BL
EARTH 102B.description: The texture, mineralogy, classification, and primal structure of     sedimentary rocks and their significance in relation to regional   setting, environment of deposition, and postdepositional history. Field  study emphasizes interpretation of sedimentary sequences.

EARTH 102C.title: Metamorphic Petrology
EARTH 102C.prereq_description: Earth 114 and 115 with a grade of C or better.
EARTH 102C.description: Study of metamorphic rocks to understand tectonic processes. Metamorphic minerals, metamorphic textures, physical processes responsible for   metamorphism, phase equilibria, thermodynamics, diffusion,     thermobarometry, kinetics, geochronology, and high-temperature rock  deformation. Lecture and lab.

EARTH 102BL.title: Sedimentology Petrology Laboratory
EARTH 102BL.prereq_description: Geology 14 or 114 or 114A-B; and Geology 15; and Geology 102B (may be
EARTH 102BL.description: Practical experience in identification of sedimentary rocks, using the   petrographic microscope, and x-ray diffraction.

EARTH 103.title: Fundamentals of Structural Geology
EARTH 103.prereq_description: Earth 104A; Math 2B or 3B (may be taken concurrently); Physics 6A or 1
EARTH 103.description: Deformation of rocks--faulting, folding and flow. Theory and observations at scales ranging from mountain belts to microscopic. Lab and lecture.

EARTH 104A.title: Field Studies in Geological Methods
EARTH 104A.description: Introduction to the methods of geological observations and       interpretations, with an emphasis on understanding earth processes in the  field and reconstructing the physical history of the earth; the    stratigraphic, petrologic, and structural relations of rocks. Geologic   report writing.

EARTH 104B.title: Field Methods
EARTH 104B.prereq_description: Earth 114 and 103. All with a C- or better.
EARTH 104B.description: Geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photographs; use of  geologic field instruments; field techniques; preparation of geologic  maps and reports. Field work is completed during the break and between winter and spring quarters.

EARTH 104G.title: Digital Analysis and Interpretation of Field Data
EARTH 104G.description: Introduction to commonly used computer programs and techniques for analyzing and visualizing surface and subsurface spatial and structural data in the Earth Sciences. Local site visits involve hands-on demonstrations in geologic data collection. Introduction to scientific writing. Lecture and Lab.

EARTH 104AH.title: Field Studies Honors Tutorial
EARTH 104AH.prereq_description: Honors standing; consent of instructor; concurrent enrollment in Earth
EARTH 104AH.description: Adjunct tutorial course with Earth 104A; emphasis on comprehensive   report preparation, writing, illustration related to geologic mapping  in the field.

EARTH 105.title: Earth?s Climate: Past and Present
EARTH 105.description: Description and quantitative analysis of climate processes and   paleoclimate proxies. Processes include radiation and the Earth?s energy budget, the influence of orbital cycles, ocean circulation, monsoons,  ENSO, and ice sheets. Paleoclimate reconstructions from tectonic-scale to the last millennium, with emphasis on glacial cycles and Plio-  Pleistocene climate evolution.

EARTH 106.title: Introduction to Climate Modeling
EARTH 106.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 206. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Fall.
EARTH 106.description: An introduction to climate models and their application to studies of past, modern, and future climate. Students will learn fundamental modeling concepts, gain experience running several kinds of models, and read/evaluate recent modeling papers. A variety of models will be introduced, with emphasis on atmosphere-ocean General Circulation  Models (GCMs) and "simple"(zero-dimensional) models. No previous modeling or programming experience is required.
EARTH 106.recommended_prep: Upper-Division standing for undergraduates.  Math 4B AND one of: Earth 4, Earth 105, Earth 130, Earth 164B, Geog 3A, Geog 110, or Geog 134.  Or instructor permission. No instructor permission required for graduate students.

EARTH 107.title: Climate Change: Lessons from the Past
EARTH 107.description: Introduction to the fundamental forces that shape and modulate the Earth's climate. Learning about climate forcings (solar insolation, albedo, greenhouse effect, ocean circulation) will provide a scientific basis to understand past, current, and future climate changes.

EARTH 108.title: Clastic Depositional Environments
EARTH 108.prereq_description: Earth 102A, Earth 114, and Earth 122 (may be taken concurrently).
EARTH 108.description: Emphasis on tectonically active settings, topics change yearly. Clastic  depositional models for alluvial fan, fan delta, and turbidite fans.   Volcaniclastic successions, including subaerial- to deepwater-erupted  pyroclastic rocks and lava flows, as well as volcanic mudflows and   sandstones. Field work completed on weekends or over spring break.

EARTH 109.title: Geology of California
EARTH 109.comments: Course materials fee required. Field Trips required.
EARTH 109.description: Introduction to the geology, geologic history, tectonic evolution, and landscape development of California. A brief survey of California's petroleum, mineral, geothermal, and water resources.

EARTH 111.title: Principles of Paleontology
EARTH 111.comments: Same course as EEMB 136. Letter grade required for majors.
EARTH 111.description: The ecologic structure and evolution of the biosphere as illustrated by  the fossil record.

EARTH 111L.title: Principles of Paleontology Laboratory
EARTH 111L.comments: Same course as EEMB 136L. Not open for credit to students who have   completed Biology 111L.
EARTH 111L.description: Exercises and projects in the identification and interpretation of   fossil taxa and fossil communities.

EARTH 113.title: Engineering and Environmental Geology
EARTH 113.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A-B or 34A-B; and, Physics 1 or 6A or 21; upper-division
EARTH 113.description: Application of geologic and environmental principles to civil      engineering problems. Includes: rock and soil mechanics; landslides;   hydrology; earthquakes; and professional practice.

EARTH 114.title: Geomaterials
EARTH 114.description: Examination of geomaterials at atomic level. Atomic structure, states  of matter, bonding, elementary phase equilibria.  Composition and    structure of atmosphere, hydrosphere, crust, mantle and core. Structure  and composition of important geochemical compounds emphasizing     rock-forming minerals.

EARTH 115.title: Analytical Methods in Geomaterials
EARTH 115.description: Optical properties of inorganic crystals; techniques of mineral identification using the polarizing microscope; strategies for studying rocks in thin section. Fundamental theory and application of electron and ion-beam instruments in quantitative characterization of geomaterials. Laboratory sessions include lectures as appropriate.

EARTH 117.title: Earth Surface Processes and Landforms
EARTH 117.comments: Additional fieldwork (10 hours) required. Meets writing requirement.   Course material fee charged.
EARTH 117.description: Introduction to the theory of landscape evolution and the study of the processes that create and modify landforms.

EARTH 118.title: Summer Field Geology
EARTH 118.prereq_description: Earth 103, 104A & 104B; one course from Earth 102A-B-C. All prerequisites require a grade of C- or better.
EARTH 118.comments: Quarters usually offered: Summer. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 118.description: Intensive hands-on training in the collection, interpretation, and presentation of geologic field data. Preparation of geologic maps, sections, and a professional report as tools to understanding geologic processes. Area and focus of investigation changes each year.

EARTH 119.title: Field Investigations in Geology
EARTH 119.prereq_description: Earth 103, 104A & 104B;  one course from Earth 102A-B-C.  All
EARTH 119.description: Selected field areas are investigated as research problems. Content varies from year to year.

EARTH 120.title: Field Paleobiology
EARTH 120.comments: May be repeated for credit to maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward the major.
EARTH 120.description: Paleontologic field studies in selected areas. Studies include the   collection, identification, and description of fossils, their systematics, paleoecology, and biostratigraphy.

EARTH 121.title: Principles of Evolution
EARTH 121.prereq_description: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3 or EARTH 2 and 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.
EARTH 121.comments: Same course as EEMB 131. Not open for credit to students who have completed Biology 131.
EARTH 121.description: A foundation course concerning the mechanisms of evolution at micro- and macroevolutionary levels, and interpretation of the resulting patterns of adaptation and organic diversity.

EARTH 122.title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy: Processes and Products
EARTH 122.prereq_description: Earth 2; and Earth 3; and Earth 104A; and Earth 114.  Field trip
EARTH 122.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 222. Letter-grade required to apply toward major. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 122.description: Transport/depositional processes, sedimentary textures and structures.   Sedimentary environments, using facies models for observation &    prediction. Principles of lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy,      chronostratigraphy, and magnetostratigraphy. Seismic stratigraphy and  sequence stratigraphic principles. Controls of tectonics, sediment   supply and eustacy on sedimentation. Lab and Lecture.

EARTH 123.title: The Solar System
EARTH 123.description: The nature and evolution of the planets of the solar system. Elementary  treatment of cosmochemistry, meteoritics, and comparative planetology  with special reference to current ideas on solar system evolution.

EARTH 124G.title: Geochronology
EARTH 124G.prereq_description: Chemistry 1A; and, Geology 2, or 3, or 4, or 4S.
EARTH 124G.description: Principles of radiogenic isotope geochronology, and applications of the  major geochronological methods to terrestrial and extraterrestrial   problems ranging from global climate change to petrology to tectonics to solar system evolution. This is a five week course.

EARTH 124I.title: Biogeochemistry of Stable and Cosmogenic Isotopes
EARTH 124I.prereq_description: Chemistry 1C; Mathematics 3A, Earth 2 or 3 or 4 or 4S.
EARTH 124I.description: Introduction to stable isotope biogeochemistry, including kinetic and  thermodynamic fractionation of stable isotopes during        evapo-precipitation, photosynthesis, and biogenic calcification.   Applications of stable isotope in environmental sciences, Quarternary  geology, paleoclimate, archeology. Introduction to mass spectrometry,  cosmogenic and radiogenic isotopes and their application in      paleoclimatology/paleoceanography.

EARTH 124T.title: Introductory Thermodynamics
EARTH 124T.description: Introduction to thermodynamics and kinetics of rock-water systems.   Calculation of mineral equilibria as a function of pressure temperature  and fluid compositions. Applied problems at surface and subsurface   conditions.

EARTH 124IG.title: Introduction to Geochemistry
EARTH 124IG.prereq_description: Earth 2 or 4; and, Earth 114; and, Chemistry 1A; and, Math 3A-B
EARTH 124IG.description: Fundamental concepts of geochemistry including radiometric dating,   inorganic chemistry, and biogeochemical cycling are introduced. The  class examines how chemical principles can be used to solve geological and environmental problems. These concepts are illustrated using   classical geology, global change, and hydrology.

EARTH 125.title: FIELD METHODS IN HYDROLOGY
EARTH 125.prereq_description: Either Earth 173 or Geography 116 or consent of
EARTH 125.description: Introduction to general field techniques used in hydrology including methods to determine river discharge, basic well and spring sampling, well water level measurements, and soil hydraulic characterization. The ~2 week class takes place at Sagehen Creek Field Station (north of Truckee, CA) in the eastern Sierra prior to the start of the Fall quarter.

EARTH 126.title: Chemical Thermodynamics for Geoscientists
EARTH 126.comments: Concurrently offered with 226. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
EARTH 126.description: Classical chemical thermodynamics with a focus on applications to    practical problems in the geosciences, environmental sciences, and   planetary sciences. This class provides a rigorous theoretical     foundation while also proving beneficial for earth and planetary     scientists seeking a review of thermodynamic principles and their    application to geological problems.

EARTH 127.title: Field Petrology
EARTH 127.prereq_description: Earth 104A and Earth 114; consent of instructor.  All prerequisites require a grade of C or better.
EARTH 127.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 227. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 127.description: Field-based study of igneous, metamorphic and tectonic processes. Investigates different topics in igneous and metamorphic petrology each year, centered around field trips to key localities. Includes lectures, review of scientific literature, on-campus labs and field-based observations and measurements.

EARTH 130.title: Global Warming - Science and Society
EARTH 130.description: Introduction to the scientific and societal issues surrounding global climate change. Includes introduction to physical climatology, greenhouse effect, climate history, anthropogenic changes, and future predictions. Student discussion and debate on the potential societal scenarios available to mitigate future climate change.

EARTH 131.title: Geophysical Time-Series Analysis
EARTH 131.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A-B and 4A-B; and Mathematics 6A (may be taken concurrently); and Physics 6A-B-C, or Physics 1 and 2.
EARTH 131.description: Time-series analysis and digital-signal processing for geophysicists. Course combines theory with practical application using MATLAB and/or Python. Topics include: sampling, the discrete Fourier transform, aliasing, convolution, filtering, power spectral density estimation, multivariate time-series analysis, and array processing.

EARTH 133.title: Plate tectonics and mantle dynamics
EARTH 133.prereq_description: Earth 2; Mathematics 3A-B-C or 3A-B and 4A-B; Mathematics 5A  or 5C or 6A (may be taken concurrently); Physics 1 and 2, or Physics 6AB-  C. Participants should have upper-division standing or consent of instructor.
EARTH 133.description: An advanced undergraduate course that takes a quantitative, physics-based approach to covering the details of plate tectonics and mantle dynamics. Using derivations at the level of Turcotte and Schubert (3Ed., 2014), the course gives undergraduates a high level understanding of the principles that govern plate strength, and the connections between plates and Earth's deep interior. Weekly lectures cover course material, while readings and take-home assignments help reinforce the concepts covered in class; discussion sections give participants the opportunity to talk through the assignments and the readings and to work through practical problem sets.

EARTH 134.title: Introduction to Geological and Geophysical Data Analysis
EARTH 134.description: Various numerical methods for analysis of data are developed. Methods are statistical inference, error propagation, least squares, time series as applied to geological and geophysical examples. Lab and lecture.

EARTH 135.title: Principles of Geophysics
EARTH 135.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A-B-C or 3A-B and 4A-B; and Mathematics 5A or 5C or 6A (may
EARTH 135.description: Basic principles in geophysics from elasticity theory, fluid dynamics,   gravity, magnetism, and heat flow. Their applications to various   processes in the earth.

EARTH 136.title: Geophysics (Seismology)
EARTH 136.prereq_description: Mathematics 3A-B-C or 3A-B and 4A-B; and, Mathematics 5A or 5C or 6A (may  be taken concurrently); and, Physics 6A-B-C, or Physics 1 and 2.
EARTH 136.description: Wave propagation in an elastic medium; reflection and refraction,    attenuation physics of the earthquake source, magnitude, seismic moment  and focal mechanisms.
EARTH 136.recommended_prep: Mathematics 5A or 5C or 6A (may be taken concurrently).  Geology 100 or  Earth 100 highly recommended.

EARTH 137.title: Quantitative Geomorphology
EARTH 137.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 237. Concurrently offered with Earth 237.
EARTH 137.description: Basic quantitative understanding of processes shaping Earth's surface. In-depth evaluation of hill slope diffusion, mass wasting, and fluvial processes. Applications of quantitative methods are emphasized throughout class.  Laboratory provides understanding of isotopic, physical, and remote sensing data.

EARTH 141.title: Plant Paleobiology
EARTH 141.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 241. Same course as EEMB 137. Letter   grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who have    completed Botany 110.
EARTH 141.description: Examination of the history of land plants; the systematics, morphology,  and phylogeny of major groups. Major evolution and biogeographic patterns.

EARTH 141L.title: Plant Paleobiology Laboratory
EARTH 141L.prereq_description: Geology 141 or EEMB 137 (may be taken concurrently).
EARTH 141L.comments: Same course as EEMB 137L. Letter grade required for majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Botany 110L.
EARTH 141L.description: Anatomy, morphology, and systematics of fossil plants from the specimens.

EARTH 143.title: The Early Evolution of Life and its Environmental Context
EARTH 143.prereq_description: MCDB 1A & MCDB 1B & EEMB 2 & EEMB 3 (all with a minimum grade of C- or
EARTH 143.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 243 . Quarters usually offered: Spring,  Fall.
EARTH 143.description: The first 3.5 billion years of life and the environmental context in   which it evolved. Highly multidisciplinary, drawing on evidence from   geology, geochemistry, paleontology, and comparative biology.

EARTH 144.title: Invertebrate Paleobiology
EARTH 144.prereq_description: MCDB 1A & MCDB 1B & EEMB 2 & EEMB 3 or Earth 3 or 30 or 111 (all with a
EARTH 144.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 244. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
EARTH 144.description: Important topics in paleobiology are discussed in the context of the   evolutionary history of invertebrate animal life. These include    macroevolutionary theory, diversification and extinction events,   ecological and geobiological interactions through time, and the    incompleteness of the fossil record.

EARTH 148.title: Vertebrate Paleontology
EARTH 148.prereq_description: Geology 2 or 3 or 7 or 30, or MCDB 1A-1AL or EEMB 2.
EARTH 148.comments: Same course as EEMB 109. Letter grade required for majors.
EARTH 148.description: Introduction to the history of vertebrate life, with emphasis on the   phylogenetic relationships of the major vertebrate groups.

EARTH 149.title: The History of Mammals
EARTH 149.prereq_description: Geological Sciences 3 or 7 or 30, or MCDB 1A-1AL; or EEMB 2.
EARTH 149.description: Introduction to the diversity of fossil and living mammals from    phylogenetic, stratigraphic, and paleobiogeographic perspectives.

EARTH 150.title: Petroleum Geology
EARTH 150.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 250. Field/Lab, 3 hours.  Course material  fee charged.
EARTH 150.description: Study of petroleum systems including origin, generation, migration, and  trapping of hydrocarbons. Guest speakers from industry. Lab includes use of basin analysis software from oil company. Field trip to active    petroleum basin in California. Required written report.

EARTH 154.title: Advanced Igneous Petrology
EARTH 154.description: The study of magma dynamics and igneous rocks including petrogeny with an emphais on petrography, physical chemistry and dynamics. Offered  alternate years.

EARTH 155.title: Petrotectonics
EARTH 155.prereq_description: Earth 114 and 115 and 102C; concurrent enrollment in Earth 155L.
EARTH 155.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 264. May be repeated for credit to a   maximum of 8 units. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 155.description: Analysis of orogenic belts using petrography, thermochronology, and  thermobarometry. Subject material changes each year.

EARTH 155L.title: Petrotectonics Lab
EARTH 155L.prereq_description: Geology 14 or 114 or 114A and 114B; and Geology 15, 102C, and 102CL;
EARTH 155L.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 264L. May be repeated for credit to a  maximum of 4 units. Course fee charged.
EARTH 155L.description: Analysis of orogenic belts using petrography, structural petrology,    thermochronology, and thermobarometry.

EARTH 156.title: Tectonic Controls on Sedimentation
EARTH 156.description: Integrates sedimentology, volcanology, structural geology, petrology, and  geophysics in the study of basins. Overview of divergent, convergent, and  strike slip margins, with textbook readings. Journal readings and field  trip to case study area, which changes yearly. Field work completed on   weekends and over spring break.

EARTH 157.title: Plate Tectonics
EARTH 157.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 235. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 157.description: Introduction to sea floor spreading, plate tectonics, and continental  drift. Geometry and evolution of present day plates. Measurement and   calculation of plate motions. Geophysical and geological implications of resulting relative motions at plate boundaries.
EARTH 157.recommended_prep: one year of university-level mathematics and physics.

EARTH 157X.title: Advanced Plate Tectonics Seminar
EARTH 157X.description: Discuss current research in plate tectonics. Supplements material    covered in Earth 157.

EARTH 158.title: Advanced Structural Geology
EARTH 158.description: Analysis of geologic-structures--theory and practice. Rock deformation as a function of crustal environment. Fault mechanics and earthquakes; mineral deformation mechanisms; microstructures, and tectonite fabrics. Finite strain measurement and interpretation of kinematic indicators. Regional structural styles.

EARTH 159.title: Origin of the Earth
EARTH 159.prereq_description: Earth 123; and, Physics 6A or 1 (may be taken concurrently).
EARTH 159.description: Origin of the earth from the perspective of planetary genesis and the  history of the solar nebula. Geochemistry and cosmochemistry of ancient  solar system materials; accretion and earliest history of the earth-moon system.

EARTH 159A.title: Origin of the Earth
EARTH 159A.prereq_description: Geology 123; and, Physics 6A or 1 (may be taken concurrently).
EARTH 159A.description: Origin of the earth from the perspective of planetary genesis and the  history of the solar nebula. Geochemistry and cosmochemistry of ancient  solar system materials; accretion and earliest history of the earth-moon system.

EARTH 159C.title: The Early Evolution of Life and its Environmental Context
EARTH 159C.description: The first 3.5 billion years of life and the environmental context in which it evolved. Highly multidisciplinary, drawing on evidence from geology,  geochemistry, paleontology, and comparative biology.

EARTH 160.title: Seminar in Geology
EARTH 160.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 260 and 268. May be repeated to a maximum  of 12 units.
EARTH 160.description: Attendance at departmental "journal club" (Earth 260, seminar in   geology) and brief written evaluations of the three papers which, in the student's judgement, were the best of the quarter.

EARTH 160W.title: Scientific writing for the Earth Sciences
EARTH 160W.comments: Students may not enroll in both Earth 160W and Earth 160 in the same quarter.
EARTH 160W.description: Introduction to written and verbal communication skills in the Earth Sciences. Students attend the weekly department colloquium or other Earth Science related presentations, and read and discuss related articles. Weekly assignments develop scientific writing skills.

EARTH 161.title: Earth Resources, Energy and the Environment
EARTH 161.comments: Course materials fee charged. Field Trip required.
EARTH 161.description: An overview of the energy resources that sustain our economies and their environmental impact. Explores the full life cycle of each resource including its geological origins, methods used to explore and develop it, uses in our economies, and the environmental impacts of these activities.

EARTH 162.title: Marine Micropaleontology and Paleobiology
EARTH 162.description: A survey of the major marine microfossil groups of the Cenozoic and    Mesozoic; with particular reference to classification, preservation,   evolution, stratigraphic utility, paleobiology, biogeography,      paleoceanographic relations and sediment accumulation.

EARTH 163.title: Organic Matters
EARTH 163.description: An introduction to the chemistry of natural organic matter in the ocean, biosphere, and geosphere. Topics include marine organic carbon production and export, fossil fuel formation, tools for identifying ancient life and paleo-environmental conditions (biomarkers, isotopes), and the global impacts of organic carbon burial on global biogeochemical cycles.

EARTH 164B.title: Earth System Ocean-Atmosphere
EARTH 164B.description: An introduction to the chemistry of the ocean and atmosphere. Topics   include composition of seawater, biogeochemical cycling, sediment    chemistry, chemical tracers of circulation, ocean-atmosphere exchange, atmospheric photochemistry and pollution, and the impact of earth system chemical changes on climate.

EARTH 164C.title: Earth System History
EARTH 164C.description: Examination of the evolution of the Earth's environmental system from  Cretaceous to present day; interactions between plate tectonics and    orogeny (lithosphere) and changes in ocean circulation (hydrosphere),  climate (atmosphere), ice sheets (cryosphere), and life (biosphere).   Globalchange theories.

EARTH 168.title: Aqueous Transport of Pollutants
EARTH 168.description: Focus on the behavior of dissolved species in rivers. Examination of the basic advection-diffusion model. Particular emphasis on field data.
EARTH 168.recommended_prep: Earth 113 or 173, or Geography 116 or 144, or Environmental Studies 144.

EARTH 169.title: Tracer and Contaminant Hydrology
EARTH 169.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 269. Same course as Environmental Studies 169.
EARTH 169.description: Introduction to principles of chemical and isotope tracer hydrology. Emphasis on methods of groundwater dating, the use of tracers as management tools, and contaminate plume monitoring.
EARTH 169.recommended_prep: Earth 113 or 173, or Geography 116 or 144, or Environmental Studies 144.

EARTH 173.title: Groundwater Hydrology
EARTH 173.prereq_description: GEOG 3B or 4 or EARTH 2; or consent of instructor.
EARTH 173.description: Analysis of groundwater flow in complex geologic environments, aquifer properties, wells and groundwater contamination, surface water-groundwater interactions. Laboratory: basic groundwater experiments, Darcy's law, flow nets, solute dispersion, field measurements of bedrock groundwater, analysis of pumping-test data.

EARTH 175.title: Introduction to MATLAB for Earth Scientists
EARTH 175.description: A 10-week introduction to coding in MATLAB including: basic programming, analysis using vectors and matrices, logical operations and indexing, data import/export, visualization and plotting, designing functions and packages, interactive user interface, and debugging.

EARTH 176.title: Geological Applications of GIS
EARTH 176.description: An intensive introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) with an emphasis on geological applications, including geologic mapping,  topographic analysis, modeling surface processes and river networks,   importation and interpolation of field data, and spatial analysis and  correlation of multiple geologic datasets. Short Lectures are    interspersed with the Lab exercises.

EARTH 177.title: Ore Deposits and Mineral Resources
EARTH 177.comments: Concurrently offered with 277. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 177.description: Distribution and characteristics of major classes of mineral deposits -  their geologic framework, mineralogy, and structure.  Lectures explore petrogenetic models for ore-formation.  Laboratory exercises and field trips stress recognition of ore and accessory minerals, zoning, and  exploration strategies.

EARTH 181.title: Field Trips in Earth Science
EARTH 181.description: Opportunity to see classic geological localities in the field. Locations vary depending on instructor(s). Lectures through the quarter cover background material needed to understand what is being observed/studied in the field. This material includes specified readings, homework assignments, exercises and exams. Lab work may also be required. Lecture, 3 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 182A.title: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry
EARTH 182A.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 282A. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 182A.description: Marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of sea-  floor mapping using  bottom photography, marine bio/geochemical sampling, and method of data  reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples   collected.  Lecture, 3 hours; labs, up to 7 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 182B.title: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry
EARTH 182B.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 282B. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 182B.description: Marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of sea-  floor mapping using  bottom photography, marine bio/geochemical sampling, and method of data  reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples   collected.  Lecture, 3 hours;  lab, up to 7 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 182E.title: Field Studies in Marine Geochemistry
EARTH 182E.description: Marine geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of sea-floor mapping using bottom   photography, marine geochemical sampling, and method of data reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples collected.

EARTH 183.title: Advanced Field Mapping and Geologic Investigations
EARTH 183.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth  283. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 183.description: Research oriented mapping projects to solve outstanding problem(s) in a  geologically significant area. Two weeks in the field, followed by   compilation and complimentary laboratory studies. Weekly meetings to   discuss results.

EARTH 185.title: Physical Volcanology
EARTH 185.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 285. Course material fee charged.
EARTH 185.description: Overview of volcanic processes, including physical properties of melts,  eruptive mechanisms, classification of volcanic deposits, and volcanic-  tectonic environments. Lecture emphasizes theoretical aspects of   volcanic processes, lab examines major classes of volcanic rocks, field  trips emphasize mapping in volcanic terrains.

EARTH 186.title: Cordilleran Tectonics
EARTH 186.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 286. Course Material fee charged.
EARTH 186.description: Directed readings, weekly seminar, and field trip focused on the   phanerozoic tectonic evolution of the North American Cordillera.   Emphasis on understanding fundamental orogenic processes (continental  extension, shortening, transcurrent motions, magmatism, metamorphism)  from a cordilleran perspective.

EARTH 187.title: Introduction to Teaching in Geological Sciences
EARTH 187.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
EARTH 187.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 4 units may be applied to the major.
EARTH 187.description: Students will assist instructors in teaching course in which the student previously received a grade of A- or better. Activities will be    determined in consultation with the instructor and may include assisting in laboratories, tutorials, discussion sections and field trips.

EARTH 189.title: Seminar in Paleobiology
EARTH 189.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
EARTH 189.description: Undergraduate seminar in advanced paleobiology involving reading and   group discussion of current literature. Option to (with faculty consent) write research papers of varying length or equivalent.

EARTH 190.title: Advanced Studies in Paleobiology
EARTH 190.comments: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 units. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 190.description: Designed to meet the interests and needs of individual students.   Selected readings and laboratory work in systematic paleontology; field  studies of recent or fossil biotas; animal-substrate relations,    biostatistics, etc.

EARTH 192.title: Internship in Geological Sciences
EARTH 192.prereq_description: Proposal form must be submitted by the end of the 2nd week of the quarter. Applicant must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.70.  Student that does not  meet this requirement may submit a GPA waiver.
EARTH 192.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward the major.
EARTH 192.description: Individualized practical approaches to problems in geological sciences by working under faculty supervision as interns with local, state or federal agencies or private organizations.  To receive credit student  must turn in an experiential journal, end of quarter evaluation, and complete the internship hours.  Units are determined by the number to  be completed at the end of the quarter.

EARTH 194AAZZ.title: Group Studies for Advanced Students
EARTH 194AAZZ.comments: Students may repeat the course; no more than five units will apply to  the major.
EARTH 194AAZZ.description: Intensive research or study by a small group of advanced students who  share an interest in a topic not included in the regular departmental  curriculum.

EARTH 195H.title: Honors Field Studies
EARTH 195H.prereq_description: Earth Science majors only; honors standing; consent of instructor.
EARTH 195H.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 195H.description: Field work in selected areas under the direction of a faculty member.  Final report required.

EARTH 196HA.title: Senior Honors Thesis
EARTH 196HA.prereq_description: Earth Science majors only; consent of instructor; honors standing (minimum
EARTH 196HA.description: Three quarter individual research project under the direction of a faculty member. Oral defense of written thesis as required by the sponsoring faculty advisor.

EARTH 196HB.title: Senior Honors Thesis
EARTH 196HB.prereq_description: Earth Science majors only; consent of instructor; honors standing (minimum
EARTH 196HB.description: Three quarter individual research project under the direction of a faculty member. Oral defense of written thesis as required by the sponsoring faculty advisor.

EARTH 196HC.title: Senior Honors Thesis
EARTH 196HC.prereq_description: Earth Science majors only; consent of instructor.
EARTH 196HC.description: Three quarter individual research project under the direction of a faculty member. Oral defense of written thesis as required by the sponsoring faculty advisor.

EARTH 197H.title: Honors Seminar in Geology
EARTH 197H.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
EARTH 197H.description: Bi-monthly, two-hour seminar to discuss advanced topics in the     geological sciences. Guest speakers.

EARTH 198.title: Readings in the Geological Sciences
EARTH 198.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of the instructor and the department chair
EARTH 198.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 grade-point average for the preceding   three quarters. May be repeated for credit, but only 4 units count toward  major. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EARTH 198.description: Critical reviews and discussions of selected geological subjects.

EARTH 199.title: Independent Studies in Geology
EARTH 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing in the major; consent of department and instructor.
EARTH 199.comments: Students must have a 3.0 grade-point-average for the preceding three   quarters. Students are limited to 5 units per quarter, 15 units per    year, and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EARTH 199.description: Course consists of academic research supervised by a faculty member.   This course is not intended for internship honors, or Senior Thesis  credit.

EARTH 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Geological Sciences
EARTH 199RA.comments: Students must have a 3.0 grade-point-average for the preceding three   quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in  all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
EARTH 199RA.description: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.

EARTH 200.title: Introduction to Geophysics
EARTH 200.description: Survey of major topics in geophysics at an elementary level; the figure of the earth, its gravitational and magnetic fields, seismology and the deep  structure of the earth, heat flow, methods of geophysical exploration. The geophysical basis of plate tectonics and sea floor spreading. Term paper.

EARTH 201A.title: Graduate Research and Field Seminar
EARTH 201A.comments: Required of all entering graduate students. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 201A.description: Field, laboratory, and analytical projects serve as an introduction to   diverse research foci and techniques in Earth Science.

EARTH 201B.title: Graduate Research Seminar
EARTH 201B.prereq_description: Earth Science 201A; graduate standing in the department of Earth Science.
EARTH 201B.comments: Required course for all first year graduate students.
EARTH 201B.description: Conducting research in Earth science: identifying significant problems;  designing effective studies; obtaining funding; writing and evaluating research proposals; following scientific ethics; using numerical   estimation; and making effective oral and written presentations.

EARTH 201C.title: Mathematical Methods in Earth Science
EARTH 201C.description: Introduces Matlab for plotting and analyzing geologic data and modeling  geologic systems. Each student will select data relevant to his/her    research for computer exercises.  Topics include statistics, Monte Carlo simulations, time series analysis, principal component analysis (EOF), and box models.

EARTH 202.title: Writing for Publication in Earth Science
EARTH 202.description: Reading assignments and discussion will focus on how to  write articles  for publication in peer-reviewed journals, particularly with respect to  style and organization. Students will submit weekly writing assignments  and receive feedback from the professor and their peers.

EARTH 205.title: Earth?s Climate: Past and Present
EARTH 205.description: Description and quantitative analysis of climate processes and     paleoclimate proxies. Processes include radiation and  the Earth?s   energy budget, the influence of orbital cycles, ocean circulation,   monsoons, ENSO, and ice sheets. Paleoclimate reconstructions from    tectonic-scale to the last millennium, with emphasis on glacial cycles and Plio-  Pleistocene climate evolution.

EARTH 206.title: Introduction to Climate Modeling
EARTH 206.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 106. Quarters usually offered: Winter,   Fall.
EARTH 206.description: An introduction to climate models and their application to studies of  past, modern, and future climate. Students will learn fundamental    modeling concepts, gain experience running several kinds of models, and  read/evaluate recent modeling papers. A variety of models will be    introduced, with emphasis on atmosphere-ocean General Circulation    Models (GCMs) and "simple" (zero-dimensional) models. No previous    modeling or programming experience is required.

EARTH 208.title: Clastic Depositional Environments
EARTH 208.description: Emphasis on tectonically active settings, topics change yearly. Clastic  depositional models for alluvial fan, fan delta, and turbidite fans.   Volcaninclastic successions, including subaerial- to deepwater-erupted   pyroclastic rocks and lava flows, as well as volcanic mudflows and   sandstones. Field work completed on weekends and over spring break.

EARTH 209.title: Tectonic Controls of Sedimentation
EARTH 209.description: Integrates sedimentology, volcanology, structural geology, petrology, and  geophysics in the study of basins. Overview of divergent, convergent, and  strike slip margins, with textbook readings. Journal readings and field  trip to case study area, which changes yearly. Field work completed on   weekends or over spring break.

EARTH 210.title: Paleoecology
EARTH 210.description: Reading and discussion of the interactions of organisms and organisms, and of organisms and the environment, in the fossil record. Specific topics  vary. Term paper required if taken for four units.

EARTH 213.title: Geochemistry II
EARTH 213.prereq_description: Chemistry 1C, Mathematics 3C, and Geology 2 or equivalent.
EARTH 213.description: An introduction to the geochemistry of the earth and solar system;   especially applications of radiogenic isotopes to problems of magma    genesisand age determination. Presentation of a seminar or term paper  selected in consultation with instructor is required.

EARTH 215.title: Isotope Geochemistry
EARTH 215.description: Course will develop isotopic systems as tracers of Earth processes, with a particular focus placed on developing radiogenic isotopic systems. The isotopic tools will be used to establish the chronology of the earliest  terrestrial events and the formation and evolution of different    reservoirs in the Earth. Applications of isotopic systems to solid Earth evolution, petrology, paleoclimate and ocean chemistry will be explored.

EARTH 216.title: Advanced Topics in Stable Isotopy
EARTH 216.prereq_description: Geological Sciences 124SI or 224SI or a similar course in stable isotopy.
EARTH 216.description: Directed reading and weekly seminar in the misuses of stable isotopy,  especially in its application to biology, archaeology, geology,    paleontology, and paleoecology. The larger issue of misues of numeric data is also addressed.

EARTH 217.title: Tectonic Geomorphology
EARTH 217.description: Interactions among geomorphic processes that shape the Earth's surface and tectonic processes that deform the upper crust. Use of new tools for   geochronology, geodesy, structural geology, and landform analysis. Field trips and projects in Southern California.

EARTH 222.title: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy: Processes and Products
EARTH 222.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 122. Course materials fee required.    Concurrently offered with Earth122.  No credit for students who have had Earth122.  Students taking the class for graduate credit must complete an  extra project (term paper or field exercise).
EARTH 222.description: Transport/depositional processes, sedimentary textures and structures.   Sedimentary environments and use of facies models for observation and  prediction. Principles of lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy,      chronostratigraphy, and magnetostratigraphy. Seismic stratigraphy and  sequence stratigraphic principles. Controls of tectonics, sediment supply  and eustacy on sedimentation.

EARTH 224G.title: Geochronology
EARTH 224G.prereq_description: Chemistry 1A; and, Geology 2, or 3, or 4, or 4S.
EARTH 224G.description: Principles of radiogenic isotope geochronology, and applications of the  major geochronological methods to terrestrial and extraterrestrial   problems ranging from global climate change to petrology to tectonics to solar system evolution. This is a five week course.

EARTH 224I.title: Biogeochemistry of Stable and Cosmogenic Isotopes
EARTH 224I.description: Introduction to stable isotope biogeochemistry, including kinetic and  thermodynamic fractionation of stable isotopes during evapo-precipitation, photosynthesis, and biogenic calcification. Applications of stable isotope in environmental sciences, Quarternary geology, paleoclimate,    archeology. Introduction to mass spectrometry, cosmogenic and radiogenic isotopes and their application in paleoclimatology/paleoceanography.

EARTH 224T.title: Introductory Thermodynamics
EARTH 224T.description: Introduction to thermodynamics and kinetics of rock-water systems.   Calculation of mineral equilibria as a function of pressure temperature  and fluid compositions. Applied problems at surface and subsurface   conditions.

EARTH 224IG.title: Introduction to Geochemistry
EARTH 224IG.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 124IG. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
EARTH 224IG.description: Fundamental concepts of geochemistry including radiometric dating,   inorganic chemistry, and biogeochemical cycling are introduced. The  class examines how chemical principles can be used to solve geological and environmental problems. These concepts are illustrated using   classical geology, global change, and hydrology.

EARTH 225.title: Advanced Igneous Petrology
EARTH 225.description: The study of magma dynamics and igneous rocks including petrogeny with an  emphasis on petrography, physical chemistry, and dynamics.

EARTH 226.title: Chemical Thermodynamics for Geoscientists
EARTH 226.comments: Concurrently offered with 126T. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
EARTH 226.description: Classical chemical thermodynamics with a focus on applications to    practical problems in the geosciences, environmental sciences, and   planetary sciences. This class provides a rigorous theoretical     foundation while also proving beneficial for earth and planetary   scientists seeking a review of thermodynamic principles and their    application to geological problems.

EARTH 227.title: Field Petrology
EARTH 227.comments: Concurrently offered with Earth 127. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 227.description: Field-based study of igneous, metamorphic and tectonic processes. Investigates different topics in igneous and metamorphic petrology each year, centered around field trips to key localities. Includes lectures, review of scientific literature, on-campus labs and field-based observations and measurements.

EARTH 231.title: Geophysical Time-Series Analysis
EARTH 231.description: Time-series analysis and digital-signal processing for geophysicists. Course combines theory with practical application using MATLAB and/or Python. Topics include: Sampling, the discrete Fourier transform, aliasing, convolution, filtering, power spectral density estimation, multivariate time-series analysis, and array processing. Students taking the class for graduate credit must complete an extra project (term paper).

EARTH 232.title: Introduction to Computing for Earth Science
EARTH 232.description: Introduction to computing and common software tools in geophysics and related disciplines. Topics include: UNIX, Python and/or MATLAB, Fortran 90, Generic Mapping Tools (GMT), LaTeX, HTML and CSS web pages, etc.

EARTH 235.title: Advanced Geophysics
EARTH 235.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 135. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 235.description: Application of geophysics principles to processes in the Earth. Use of   gravity, elasticity theory, fluid dynamics, geomagnetism, and theory of  heat transfer.  Term paper required.

EARTH 236.title: Geophysics Seismology
EARTH 236.prereq_description: One year of college level calculus and physics.
EARTH 236.description: Wave propagation in an elastic medium; reflection and refraction,    attenuation. Physics of the earthquake source, magnitude, seismic moment and focal mechanisms.

EARTH 237.title: Quantitative Geomorphology
EARTH 237.description: Basic quantitative understanding of processes shaping Earth's surface.   In-depth evaluation of hill slope diffusion, mass wasting, and fluvial processes. Applications of quantitative methods are emphasized     throughout class.  Laboratory provides understanding of isotopic,    physical, and remote sensing data.

EARTH 239.title: Origin of the Earth
EARTH 239.description: Origin of the Earth from the perspective of planetary genesis and the  history of the Solar Nebula. Geochemistry and cosmochemistry of ancient  solar system materials; accretion and earliest history of the Earth-Moon system.

EARTH 240A.title: Mineralogical Thermodynamics
EARTH 240A.description: Derivation of thermodynamic equations of state for minerals and fluids.  Thermodynamics of ideal and nonideal crystalline solutions. Development  and application of thermodynamic data bases. Characterization of physical  conditions for metamorphic and igneous rocks.

EARTH 241.title: Plant Paleobiology
EARTH 241.description: Examination of the history of land plants; the systematics, morphology,  and phylogeny of major groups. Major evolutionary and biogeographic    patterns. Extra readings and paper.

EARTH 243.title: The Early Evolution of Life and its Environmental Context
EARTH 243.description: The first 3.5 billion years of life and the environmental context in which it evolved.  Highly multidisciplinary, drawing on evidence from geology, geochemistry, paleontology, and comparative biology.

EARTH 244.title: Invertebrate Paleobiology
EARTH 244.description: Important topics in paleobiology are discussed in the context of the   evolutionary history of invertebrate animal life. These include    macroevolutionary theory, diversification and extinction events,     ecological and geobiological interactions through time, and the    incompleteness of the fossil record.

EARTH 245.title: Sequence Stratigraphy
EARTH 245.comments: Course materials fee required. Open to upper division undergraduates who meet prerequisites of Earth 122.
EARTH 245.description: Fundamental concepts of sequence stratigraphy.  Students will learn how to use seismic lines, core data, and stratigraphic columns to create a    sequence stratigraphic framework for a basin and apply that framework to different geological problems.  Fieldtrips will be required.

EARTH 247.title: Seminar in Quaternary Geology
EARTH 247.description: Selected topics in quaternary geology. Subject matter changes from year to year.

EARTH 248.title: Vertebrate Paleontology
EARTH 248.description: Introduction to the history of vertebrate life, with emphasis on the   phylogenetic relationships of the major vertebrate groups. Paper required.

EARTH 249.title: History of Mammals
EARTH 249.prereq_description: EARTH 3 or 7 or 11 or 30, or MCDB 5A-AL.
EARTH 249.description: Introduction to the diversity of fossil and living mammals from    phylogenetic, stratigraphic, and paleobiogeographic perspectives.    Required research paper.

EARTH 250.title: Petroleum Geology
EARTH 250.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 150. Field/Lab, 3 hours.  Course   materials fee required.
EARTH 250.description: Study of petroleum systems including origin, generation, migration, and  trapping hydrocarbons. Guest speakers from industry. Field trip to   active petroleum basin in California. Required written report.

EARTH 251A.title: Matrix Analysis and Computation
EARTH 251A.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra,  mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211A, ME 210A, ECE 210A, and Chemical Engineering 211A.
EARTH 251A.description: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations.   SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues,    perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.

EARTH 251B.title: Numerical Simulation
EARTH 251B.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra,  mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211B, ME 210B, ECE 210B, Chemical Engineering 211B,  and Math 206B.
EARTH 251B.description: Linear multistep methods and Runge-Kutta methods for ordinary differential equations: stability, order and convergence. Stiffness. Differential   algebraic equations. Numerical solution of boundary value problems.

EARTH 251C.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Difference  Methods
EARTH 251C.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra,  mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211C, ME 210C, ECE 210C, Chemical Engineering 211C,  and Math 206C.
EARTH 251C.description: Finite difference methods for hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic PDE's,  with application to problems in science and engineering. Convergence,  consistency, order and stability of finite difference methods. Dissipation and dispersion. Finite volume methods. Software design and adaptivity.

EARTH 251D.title: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations - Finite Element  Methods
EARTH 251D.comments: Students should be proficient in basic numerical methods, linear algebra,  mathematically rigorous proofs, and some programming language. Same course as Computer Science 211D, ME 210D, ECE 210D, Chemical Engineering 211D,  and Math 206D.
EARTH 251D.description: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of     hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic partial differential equations, with  application to problems in science and engineering. Error estimates.   Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.

EARTH 253.title: Mineral Separations Practicum
EARTH 253.description: Learn to prepare high purity mineral separates (e.g., zircon, apatite,   monazite, K-feldspar, mica, plagioclase) from rocks or sediments for   geochronologic or petrologic purposes.  Crushing, grinding, sieving,   magnetic and density separations, acid treatments. Design safe and   efficient separation strategies.

EARTH 254.title: Advanced Seismology Seminar
EARTH 254.description: Reading and class discussion of basic concepts and methods of seismology,  current discoveries and unsolved problems.

EARTH 255.title: Advanced Geophysics
EARTH 255.description: Selected topics in advanced geophysics, including seismology, seismo-acoustics and infrasound, gravity, magnetism, geodynamics, volcano geophysics, and the application of techniques for geophysical analysis.

EARTH 256.title: Geophysical Inverse Theory
EARTH 256.description: Introduction to basic concepts of inverse theory such as resolution, error and its trade-off. Application to earth structure study, earthquake    source,geodetic data and magnetic field. Reading on key papers. Term paper.

EARTH 257.title: Plate Tectonics Seminar
EARTH 257.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 157. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 257.description: Read recent related articles. Students present and discuss selected topics in separate seminar. Complete term paper and/or problem sets for three or  four units.

EARTH 258.title: Advanced Structural Geology
EARTH 258.comments: Concurrently offered. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 258.description: Analysis of geologic structures--theory and practice. Rock deformation as  a function of crustal environment. Fault mechanics and earthquakes;    mineral deformation mechanisms; microstructures, and tectonite fabrics.  Finite strain measurement and interpretation of kinematic indicators.  Regional structural styles.

EARTH 259.title: Advanced Stratigraphic and Geomorphic Field Methods

EARTH 259C.title: The Early Evolution of Life and its Environmental Context
EARTH 259C.description: The first 3.5 billion years of life and the environmental context in which it evolved. Highly multidisciplinary, drawing on evidence from geology,  geochemistry, paleontology, and comparative biology.

EARTH 260.title: Seminar in Geology
EARTH 260.comments: Concurrently offered with GEOL 160. Required of all first-year graduate  students. May be repeated for credit.
EARTH 260.description: Presentation and discussion of current research, and reviews of the    literature on selected geologic concepts. Students present material    reflecting their interests in geology for critical appraisal, of both  content and manner of presentation, by selected members of the seminar.  Emphasis is placed on assisting students in developing professional    speaking style.

EARTH 260OR.title: Earth Science Outreach
EARTH 260OR.description: Active participation in an outreach program for local schools, presenting Earth Science concepts, demonstrations, samples and experiments to a diverse group of K-12 students, with the mission to ignite their interest in STEM, and make scientists more approachable.

EARTH 261.title: Marine Stratigraphy
EARTH 261.comments: Open to graduates and qualified senior undergraduates. Short field trips.
EARTH 261.description: Extensive reading and class discussion of concepts and methods of marine stratigraphy. Included are lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy,     chemostratigraphy, magnetostratigraphy, chronostratigraphy, and    chronology. Stratigraphic nomenclature. Problems and advances in     correlation and dating of sediments including the Pacific, California, and Europe. Term paper.

EARTH 262.title: Marine Micropaleontology and Paleobiology
EARTH 262.description: A survey of the major marine microfossil groups of the cenozoic and    mesozoic; with particular reference to classification, preservation,   evolution, stratigraphic utility, paleobiology, biogeography,      paleoceanographic relations, and sediment accumulation.

EARTH 263.title: Organic Matters
EARTH 263.description: An introduction to the chemistry of natural organic matter in the ocean, biosphere, and geosphere. Topics include marine organic carbon production and export, fossil fuel formation, tools for identifying ancient life and paleo-environmental conditions (biomarkers, isotopes), and the global impacts of organic carbon burial on global biogeochemical cycles. Term paper required for graduate section.

EARTH 264.title: Petrotectonics
EARTH 264.comments: Concurrently offered. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 264.description: Analysis of orogenic belts using petrography, thermochronology, and    thermobarometry. Subject material changes each year.

EARTH 264L.title: Petrotectonics Laboratory
EARTH 264L.description: Analysis of orogenic belts using petrography, structural petrology,    thermochronology, and thermobarometry.

EARTH 266.title: Chemical Oceanography
EARTH 266.description: An introduction to the chemistry of the oceans. Topics include     composition and chemical equilibria of seawater, biogeochemical cycling, sediment chemistry, atmospheric exchange, circulation and rates of   mixing based on chemical tracers, and the impact of ocean chemistry on climate change.

EARTH 267.title: Climates of the Past
EARTH 267.description: Introduction to climate and ocean history. Techniques used to reconstruct  terrestrial, oceanic and atmospheric conditions. Evolution of climate over the last million years. Theories of climate change, including Milankovich  hypothesis, greenhouse effect and internal feedback. Anthropogenic climate change.

EARTH 268.title: Seminar in Geology-Presentation
EARTH 268.description: Presentation of research topics to meeting of Geology 260.

EARTH 269.title: Tracer and Contaminant Hydrology
EARTH 269.comments: Offered concurrently with Geology 169 and Environmental Studies 169.
EARTH 269.description: Introduction to principles of chemical and isotope tracer hydrology.   Emphasis on methods of groundwater dating, the use of tracers as     management tools, and contaminate plume monitoring. Research paper   required.

EARTH 270AAZZ.title: Seminar in Geologic Problems
EARTH 270AAZZ.description: Review and discussion of a current problem in geology. Content is    variable and depends on student interest.

EARTH 272.title: Special Topics In Earth Science
EARTH 272.description: Lecture-based exploration and review of special topics in Earth Science. Content is variable and depends on student interest.

EARTH 276.title: Geological Oceanography
EARTH 276.description: Morphology, formation, and evolution of ocean basins; crustal structure  and composition of ocean margins; source and composition of marine   sediments; marine sediment as repository of paleoclimate and paleo-ocean circulation records.  Paleoceanographic changes in relation to tectonics and changes in orbital parameters, links between changes in ocean    circulation and climate changes.

EARTH 277.title: Ore Deposits and Mineral Resources
EARTH 277.comments: Concurrently offered with 177. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 277.description: Distribution and characteristics of major classes of mineral deposits -  their geologic framework, mineralogy, and structure.  Lectures explore petrogenetic models for ore-formation.  Laboratory exercises and field trips stress recognition of ore and accessory minerals, zoning, and  exploration strategies.

EARTH 280.title: Seminar in Field Geology
EARTH 280.comments: Credit is one half of one unit per day in the field, with a maximum of one unit for any trip. May be repeated for a maximum of eight units each   academic year.
EARTH 280.description: Field trips of one day or more, organized as opportune. Appropriate report required for each trip.

EARTH 281.title: Field Trips in Earth Science
EARTH 281.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 181. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 281.description: Opportunity to see classic geological localities in the field. Locations vary depending on instructor(s).  Lectures through the quarter cover background material needed to understand what is being observed/studied in the field. This material includes specified readings, homework assignments, exercises and exams. Lab work may also be required.  Lecture, 3 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 282A.title: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry
EARTH 282A.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 182A. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 282A.description: Studies in marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of seafloor mapping  using bottom photography, marine bio/geochemical sampling, and methods of  data reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples  collected.  Lecture, 3 hours;  lab, up to 7 hours;  field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 282B.title: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry
EARTH 282B.comments: Concurrently offered with EARTH 282B. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 282B.description: Studies in marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of seafloor mapping  using bottom photography, marine bio/geochemical sampling, and methods of  data reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples  collected.  Lecture, 3 hours; lab, up to 7 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.

EARTH 283.title: Advanced Field Mapping and Geologic Investigations
EARTH 283.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 183. Course materials fee charged.
EARTH 283.description: Research-oriented mapping projects to solve outstanding problem(s) in a  geologically significant area. Two weeks in the field, followed by   compliation and complimentary laboratory studies. Weekly meetings to   discuss results. Paper required.

EARTH 284.title: Sequence Stratigraphy
EARTH 284.description: Overview of the methods and applications of sequence stratigraphy.  The  primary focus will be on siliciclastic systems but basic principles    applied to carbonate systems will also be reviewed. Exercises will require the interpretation of cores, outcrops, and seismic reflection data.

EARTH 285.title: Physical Volcanology
EARTH 285.prereq_description: Geology 14 or 114 or 114A-B; and Geology 102A and 104A.
EARTH 285.comments: Concurrently offered with Geology 185. Course materials fee required.
EARTH 285.description: Overview of volcanic processes, including physical properties of melts,  eruptive mechanisms, classification of volcanic deposits, and      volcanic-tectonic environments. Lecture emphasizes theoretical aspects of  volanic processes, lab examines major classification of rocks. Graduate  students must complete an independent research project.

EARTH 286.title: Cordilleran Tectonics
EARTH 286.description: Directed readings, weekly seminar, and field trip focused on the     phanerozoic tectonic evolution of the North American Cordillera. Emphasis  on understanding fundamental orogenic processes (continental extension,  shortening, transcurrent motions, magmatism, metamorphism) from a    cordilleran perspective.

EARTH 501.title: Practicum in Instruction
EARTH 501.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
EARTH 501.description: Practical experience in teaching in geological sciences. Student will have responsibility for one or more laboratory and/or discussion sections.  Evaluations will be made by both staff and class.

EARTH 501MT.title: Practicum in Mentoring
EARTH 501MT.description: Practical experience in mentoring undergraduates in Earth Science. Activities range from teaching laboratory and field skills, to supervising independent research, to advising students in their preparation and application for graduate school or career planning.

EARTH 502.title: Teaching Assistant Training
EARTH 502.comments: Maximum of three quarters. No unit credit allowed toward degree.
EARTH 502.description: Orientation and workshop in professional conduct and responsibilities.   Course will involve observation of student in teaching situation (faculty  visits or videotaping) and follow-up conferences, evaluations, and   follow-up.

EARTH 503.title: Practicum in Research
EARTH 503.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
EARTH 503.description: Practical experience in research in the geological sciences, under   supervision of faculty member.

EARTH 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
EARTH 596.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.
EARTH 596.comments: No more than half the units necessary for the master's degree may be taken in geology 596.
EARTH 596.description: Individual tutorial. Written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the instructor and the department chair.

EARTH 597.title: Individual Study for Master's and Ph.D. Examinations
EARTH 597.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.
EARTH 597.comments: No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
EARTH 597.description: Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of the committee.

EARTH 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
EARTH 598.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.
EARTH 598.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
EARTH 598.description: Instructor normally should be chair of the student's thesis committee.   Only for research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis.

EARTH 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
EARTH 599.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.
EARTH 599.description: Instructor normally should be chair of thestudent's doctoral committee.  Only for research underlying thedissertation, writing the dissertation.  Limited to terminal preparation.
